clinical_study.brief_title: Non Carbonic Buffer Power of Critical Ill Patients With Sepsis
clinical_study.official_title: Changes in Acid-base Variables Induced by Acute Variations in Partial Pressure of Carbon Dioxide in Whole Blood and Isolated Plasma of Septic Critically Ill Patients and Healthy Volunteers: an In-vitro Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda, Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico

clinical_study.source: Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda, Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico

brief_summary.textblock:
Alterations of acid-base equilibrium are very common in critically ill patients and understanding their pathophysiology can be important to improve clinical treatment.
The human organism is protected against acid-base disorders by several compensatory mechanisms that minimize pH variations in case of blood variations in carbon dioxide content. The aim of the present study is to quantify the buffer power, i.e. the capacity to limit pH variations in response to carbon dioxide changes, in critically ill septic patients and compare these results with data collected from healthy volunteers.

detailed_description.textblock:
Alterations of acid-base equilibrium are very common in critically ill patients and understanding their pathophysiology can be important to improve clinical treatment.
The human body is protected against acid-base disorders by several compensatory mechanisms that minimize pH variations in response to acid-base derangements.
The present study focuses on the acute compensatory mechanisms of respiratory acid-base derangements, i.e., respiratory acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. In this case the non-carbonic buffers are constituted by albumin and phosphates in plasma, with the addition of hemoglobin in whole blood.
Aim of the present in-vitro study is to measure the buffer power of non-carbonic weak acids contained in whole blood and isolated plasma, assess the relative contribution of red blood cells and plasma proteins and perform a comparison between septic patients and healthy controls.

primary_outcome.description: Non-carbonic buffer power (beta) of whole blood and isolated plasma [expressed as variations in bicarbonate concentration divided by variations in pH).

secondary_outcome.measure: Strong Ion Difference variations induced by carbon dioxide
secondary_outcome.description: Variations in Strong Ion Difference of whole blood and plasma [expressed in milliequivalents per Liter], induced by acute in vitro changes of carbon dioxide

secondary_outcome.measure: Bicarbonate Variations induced by carbon dioxide
secondary_outcome.description: Variations in bicarbonate concentration of whole blood and plasma [expressed in milliequivalents per Liter], induced by acute in vitro changes of carbon dioxide
Oxidized albumin [expressed as percentage of total albumin concentration]

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between hematocrit values and Strong Ion Difference variations
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between hematocrit [expressed as percentage] values and Strong Ion Difference variations [expressed in mEq/L] induced by acute in vitro changes of Carbon Dioxide. Acute variations in partial pressure of carbon dioxide cause changes in Strong Ion Difference. The hypothesis is that the magnitude of Strong Ion Difference variations correlate to the hematocrit, being the red blood cell the major source of electrolytes. The higher the hematocrit, the higher the possible change in Strong Ion Difference induced by acute variations in partial pressure of carbon dioxide.

arm_group.description: Patients with sepsis or septic shock according to the SEPSIS-III (Singer M Jama 2016) admitted to the general Intensive Care Unit
Subjects without known respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, renal or hematologic diseases.

intervention.intervention_name: In vitro determination of non-carbonic buffer power
intervention.description: In vitro measurement of the non-carbonic buffer power by the means of equilibration of whole blood and isolated plasma with gas mixtures containing different concentrations of carbon dioxide
Measurement of plasma electrolytes, hemoglobin concentration, albumin and phosphates to compute acid-base variables according to Stewart's approach.

study_pop.textblock: Patients with sepsis or septic shock admitted to the ICU will be enrolled. Furthermore, healthy volunteers recruited from ICU staff members and relatives will be enrolled as control group.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Septic patients and healthy volunteers
Exclusion Criteria:
- age < 18 years and pregnancy
